description: From Latin analogus, from Ancient Greek ᾰ̓νᾰ́λογος (análogos);   Its English equivalent is analogy +‎ -ous. The application to similar features of organisms is nearly as old as the general sense.  Recognizably modern uses of the second sense, distinguishing analagous from homologous, appear in the mid-19th century.

adjectives.description: analogous (comparative more analogous, superlative most analogous)

entries.meaning: Having analogy; corresponding to something else; bearing some resemblance or proportion (often followed by "to".)
examples: Analogous tendencies in arts and in manners.

entries.meaning: (biology) Functionally similar, but arising through convergent evolution rather than being homologous.
